As a petroleum engineer, I have to be careful forecasting questions where I have enhanced and lengthy experience. As such I develop a bias that is harder to shake with new data that should sway me.  Citgo is a refiner. The refining business is very, very stable. Fuel consumption is very predictable, storage is stable, transport costs are predictable.  The business side of this question has no indicators of large uncertainty or surprise costs.
There have been floods that may or may not have affected the business, but that isn't why this question was proposed, It is because of the Venezuelan sanctions, as Citgo is wholly owned by the government of Venezuela. 
  In March, 2019 the US Treasury took the unusual steps to refinance Citgo to keep those American jobs.  Cited- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citgo
Further, I've found good intel on health of companies based on their hiring practices, in this case, hiring is normal - http://www.citgo.com/careers/opportunities/current-opportunities
There is absolutely no google news since Q1 about a possible bankruptcy. A leak about it would be highly likely, so I up my prediction there is no bankruptcy coming. As a good forecaster, I must list that which would make me think I'm wrong:
- credible news leaks of a bankruptcy
- sudden delisting of higher and middle  management jobs
- soft pre-breaking hints from Citgo's website of 'restructure'
- news of Citgo assets shutting down or selling off

PDV 2020 bond is secured by 50.1pc of the shares of Citgo´s indirect parent company PdV Holding(PDVH).  PdV has made $71mn interest payment in April 2019 and will owe $842mn in principal in October 2019 on the 2020 bond.
Very unlikely(1%<) that Citgo will file for bakruptcy protection before 1 August 2019 because of that obligation. The other 49.9pc of the PDVH shares is pledged to Russian state-controlled Rosneft for an oil-backed loan of $1.5bn. I think, there is also very low probability (1%<) Rosneft will claim its rights on Citgo assets before 1 August 2019  (until they have Maduro sending oil to them as repayments for loan). That leaves Canadian mining company Crystallex International claim on Citgo assets as a major reason for Citgo to use bankruptcy protection. But it seems, that Crystallex will not succeed before 1 August to get a definitive ruling from US Court system. I give 5% to the negative for Citgo scenario (I am not an expert in US legal system and could be making mistake here).

Venezuelan crude oil production falls to lowest level since January 2003
In March 2019, Venezuela's crude oil production (excluding condensate) averaged 840,000 barrels per day (b/d), down from 1.1 million b/d in February, according to estimates in the U.S. Energy Information Administration's (EIA) April 2019 Short-Term Energy Outlook.  This average is the lowest level since January 2003, when a nationwide strike and civil unrest largely brought Venezuela's state oil company, Petróleos de Venezuela, S.A.'s (PdVSA), operations to a halt. Widespread power outages, mismanagement of the country's oil industry, and U.S. sanctions directed at Venezuela's energy sector and PdVSA have all contributed to the recent declines. Venezuela's production decreased by an average of 33,000 b/d each month in 2018, and the rate of decline accelerated to an average of over 135,000 b/d per month in the first quarter of 2019. The number of active oil rigs—an indicator of future oil production—also fell from nearly 70 rigs in the first quarter of 2016 to 24 rigs in the first quarter of 2019. The declines in Venezuelan production will have limited effects on the United States, as U.S. imports of Venezuelan crude oil have decreased over the last several years, with average 2018 imports the lowest since 1989. However, there may be upward pressure on the prices of other crude oils imported into the United States.

CITGO is an insulated entity. The opco and holdco stand alone credit profile plus the potential for government support is higher than the group credit profile. The subsidiary's financial performance and funding prospects are highly independent from those of the group, so that even if other core entities encounter severe setbacks, the relative strength of the subsidiary will remain nearly intact. The subsidiary is severable from the group and able to stand on its own or subcontract certain functions previously provided by the parent. The parent's strategy with respect to the subsidiary is clear and, in particular, the parent has a compelling economic incentive to preserve the subsidiary's credit strength; and it is unlikely that the subsidiary will be drawn into bankruptcy proceedings at the group level that would lead to a default on the subsidiary's obligations. Additionally, CITGO holds itself out as a separate entity and maintains arm's-length relationships with its affiliates; it doesn't commingle its funds, other assets, and cash flows with those of any other entity; it maintains its own records, books of account, financial statements, and other corporate documents separate from those of any other company; and it pays its own liabilities out of its own funds and observes all corporate formalities. In situations where the group credit profile is in the 'CCC' category (as is the case with PDVSA), the issuer credit rating on an insulated subsidiary will be no lower than 'B-'.  Additionally, when the 2015 CITGO Holdings bond was issued, covenants were put in place which effectively limit the likelihood that CITGO will 1. be able to incur significant additional debt and 2. dividend the proceeds of any such incremental debt to PDVSA. Beyond this, there exist covenants that impact the ability of CITGO to raise additional debt at both the CITGO Petroleum and CITGO Holding levels. CITGO Petroleum covenants include - financial covenant of debt to capitalization of 60%, restricted payments test of debt to capitalization of 55% and minimum liquidity of $500 million and any restricted payments cannot exceed 100% of net income, and an additional pari passu debt limited to $1 billion in aggregate, as well as baskets for a project finance of $250 million inventory financing of $300 million. CITGO Holding covenants include - financial covenant of debt to capitalization of 75%, restricted payments test that CITGO Holding leverage must be less than 2x plus 18 months of debt service on all debt must be reserved, and that the additional CITGO Petroleum indebtedness listed above of up to $1 billion can only be more than $500 million if CITGO Holding's leverage is less than 1.5x. With regard to PDVSA collateralizing loans from Rosneft with its CITGO equity, PDVSA is domiciled in Venezuela but the CITGO entities are U.S. companies, subject to U.S. law. Rosneft, which is majority owned by Russia, is currently the subject of financial sanctions imposed by the U.S. in 2014 following Russia's 2014 annexation of Crimea. Under U.S. law, these sanctions prevent Rosneft from gaining control of U.S. assets. CITGO represents the most significant offshore assets of PDVSA. Given that CITGO will likely not be included in the bankruptcy of PDVSA should it occur, it is more likely that PDSVA would seek a buyer for the company as a means to receive as much value as possible.

Citigroup to sell Venezuelan gold in setback to President Maduro: sources With Washington’s support, Guaido’s team has taken control of state oil company PDVSA’s U.S. refining subsidiary but its attempt to negotiate a 120-day extension of the repurchase deadline for the collateral was unsuccessful, the sources said. “Citibank was told that there was a force majeure event in Venezuela, so the grace period was necessary, but they did not grant it,” said one of the sources, who belongs to Guaido’s team.  Guaido’s team also began preparing this month for a possible debt restructuring in a bid to ease payments and stop any hostile action by creditors, said two sources who took part in the discussion. In meetings between members of Guaido’s team with legal advisors in the United States, there were discussions of starting renegotiations soon not only with Venezuelan bondholders, but also with the Chinese and Russian governments and companies affected by a wave of nationalizations, said the sources. “We want to address the debt in a comprehensive way. We calculate that it totals $200 billion,” said one of the sources. The Citgo refinery unit, Venezuela’s main asset abroad, is under scrutiny because it serves as a guarantee for the issuance of a PDVSA bond and a loan from Russian oil company Rosneft. Guaido’s advisers are also evaluating the payment in the coming weeks of around $72 million in interest coming due on PDVSA’s 2020 bonds to avoid any action by creditors against Citgo. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-gold-idUSKCN1R12GR

There is no bed for so many people.  A federal judge in Delaware ruled in August 2018 that Venezuela’s discretionary control of PDVSA rendered the company the “alter ego” of the government. In other words, the two entities are one and the same, and therefore, the assets of one could be used to pay the debts of the other. In a report from September 2017, legal experts estimated that Venezuela’s exposure to these claims was around $16 billion. This means that even if we don’t consider other possible claims coming from other bondholders and companies, the value of CITGO assets will not cover all claims. To put it simply in Caribbean Spanish: “no hay cama pa’ tanta gente”.

This is a question of time.
Maduro has no interest on paying the debt and interests (PDVSA's 2020 bond) as he has no access to proceeds or funds to keep him in power. This is the same reason Guaidó wants to "protect and control the Venezuelan assets" (plus, maybe, he is thinking about the future). CITGO has been challenged in the past as alter ego of PDVSA in other litigations. There could also be a motivation for Maduro to default, the $1.5B loan from Rosneft, backed with 49.9% of CITGO as collateral to give half of the company to his friend and supporter Putin. US administration will not let this happen and I assume Guaidó will try to avoid this at any cost as well. So, Guaidó is buying time by using the escrow funds to pay interests due in April in the hope of a quick resolution of the political situation. If this is not the case, the US will issue an asset protection order before PDVSA defaults and triggers the CITGO collateral. Chances are the Trump administration will give Guaidó authorisation to use the escrow account, then political situation will be solved before August 1st, and if no the case, then the company will file for bankruptcy protection, but not necessarily before August 1st.
